In right $\triangle ADC$, $CD = AC \cos(45^\circ) = 3\sqrt{2} \times \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} = 3$.

Also, $AH = 2R \cos A$.
$AH = 2R \cos A$, $HD = 2R \cos B \cos C$.
Using the formula for altitudes, we have
$AH = 2R \cos A = 2 \frac{4}{2 \sin 45^\circ} \cos A = \frac{4}{\sqrt{2}} \cos A = 2 \sqrt{2} \cos A$
$HD = 2R \cos B \cos C$.
If $BC = 4$, $AC = 3\sqrt{2}$ and $\angle C = 45^\circ$, then by Law of Sines,
$\frac{BC}{\sin A} = \frac{AC}{\sin B} = \frac{AB}{\sin 45^\circ}$.
$AD = 3$, $AH = 2R \cos A$.
$AH/HD = 2 \times \cos(C) / (1-\cos(C)) = 2 \times \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} / (1-1/\sqrt{2}) = \sqrt{2} / (1 - 1/\sqrt{2}) = 2 \times \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} / (1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}) = \frac{2}{\sqrt{2}} / \frac{\sqrt{2}-1}{\sqrt{2}} = \frac{2}{\sqrt{2}-1} = 2(\sqrt{2}+1) = 2\sqrt{2} + 2$.
$AH/HD = 2$.
$AH:HD = 2:1$
